trial_identification.studytitle: Management of eye emergencies in the emergency department by resident medical officers
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Assessing the training of resident medical officers in Queensland Health emergency departments in dealing with eye emergencies, their own perceived level of confidence and competence in managing such cases, and the availability of appropriate equipment in their departments.

interventions.interventions: Level of confidence and experience resident medical officers have in dealing with ophthalmic emergencies following a minimum of 10 weeks experience.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Percentage of particpants that are not confident with ophthalmic emergencies. They will be asked to reply on a survey either: (a) Not confident (b) A little confident (c) Confident The percentage of each response will be collated.

Percentage of particpants that are not confident with measuring intra-ocular pressure. They will be asked to reply on a survey either: (a) Not confident (b) A little confident (c) Confident The percentage of each response will be collated.

Percentage of particpants that are not confident with using a slit lamp. They will be asked to reply on a survey either: (a) Not confident (b) A little confident (c) Confident The percentage of each response will be collated.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Resident medical officers working for Queensland Health who have a minimum of 10 weeks experience in emergency department.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: No experience or less then 10 weeks working in an emergency department

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 60 Upper Cairns Terrace Red Hill 4059 Qld, Australia

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To assess the training of resident medical officers in emergency departments in dealing with eye emergencies, their own perceieved level of confidence and competence in managing such cases, and the availability of appropriate equipment in their departments.
